content:
Nephrotic syndrome: Causes, symptoms and treatment

Nephrotic syndrome shows that the kidneys are in an abnormal condition. The physiological functions of the kidney are now disturbed. Without early intervention, patients can face extremely dangerous complications.

What is nephrotic syndrome?
Nephrotic syndrome is a condition in which the body loses protein through urine > 3g of protein/day. The cause is glomerular damage accompanied by edema and hypoalbuminemia. This syndrome is more common in children, and has both primary and secondary causes. (first)
Nephrotic syndrome is caused by glomerular damage accompanied by edema and hypoalbuminemia

Symptoms of nephrotic syndrome
People with nephrotic syndrome will have symptoms such as:
Swelling: This symptom often appears around the eyes, ankles and feet, and may be accompanied by peritoneal and pleural effusion; Urine appears foamy; Increased body weight due to excess water not being able to escape; Poor appetite, fatigue; Loss of appetite.

Causes of nephrotic syndrome
The cause of nephrotic syndrome is inflammation and damage to the glomerular filtration membrane. The function of the glomerular filtration membrane is to filter blood in the body as it passes through the kidneys. Healthy glomeruli keep proteins in the blood (albumin) from passing through the filter membrane.
When the glomerular filtration membrane becomes inflamed, too much protein in the blood will seep through the membrane, leading to nephrotic syndrome. Most cases of nephrotic syndrome in young people have no cause (primary nephrotic syndrome).

Factors that can cause nephrotic syndrome
Factors that increase the risk of nephrotic syndrome include: (2)
Suffering from certain diseases that affect the whole body such as diabetes, lupus, amyloidosis...; Long-term use of certain medications such as non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, antibiotics, etc.; Suffering from certain infectious diseases such as HIV, hepatitis B, hepatitis C, malaria...; Certain types of cancer.
People with lupus have a very high risk of developing nephrotic syndrome

Complications of nephrotic syndrome
Complications of nephrotic syndrome can be dangerous such as:
High blood cholesterol and blood triglycerides: Reduced levels of albumin protein in the blood cause the liver to produce more albumin. At the same time, the liver releases more cholesterol and triglycerides; Malnutrition: When the body loses too much protein in the blood, it can become malnourished. This condition causes severe weight loss that is difficult to notice because the body is swollen. In addition, the body may also have a decrease in the number of red blood cells (anemia), vitamin D and calcium.; High blood pressure: A patient's blood pressure can increase due to excess salt and water retention in the body; Acute kidney failure: When the kidneys lose the ability to filter blood due to glomerular damage, waste can quickly accumulate in the blood. At that time, the patient may need urgent dialysis.; Chronic kidney disease: Nephrotic syndrome, when not treated promptly and the condition persists for a long time, can lead to chronic kidney function deterioration. When kidney function is greatly reduced, the patient may need hemodialysis or a kidney transplant.; Infection: People with nephrotic syndrome are at high risk of infection; Increases blood clotting, leading to the formation of venous thrombosis in the legs or elsewhere.
Nephrotic syndrome can cause high blood pressure

When to see a doctor?
Patients need to see a doctor immediately if the above symptoms appear, especially foamy urine. Early diagnosis and treatment will slow down disease progression, help restore health faster, avoid unfortunate complications, especially reduce the risk of chronic kidney failure.

What should you do when you discover you have nephrotic syndrome?
The best way to control the symptoms of nephrotic syndrome is to take medication as prescribed by your doctor. Besides, patients need to maintain a diet with appropriate amounts of potassium and protein; while reducing sodium, saturated fat and cholesterol intake. (3)
Patients can improve swelling by limiting the amount of sodium in their diet. Most sodium in the diet comes from salt. Additionally, you can also help reduce swelling by limiting your fluid intake.
Reducing saturated fat and cholesterol in the diet can help control hyperlipidemia. Patients should limit foods such as full-fat dairy, red meat, cheese, fried foods, baked foods and sweets.

How to diagnose nephrotic syndrome
1. Criteria for diagnosing nephrotic syndrome
Phew.; Increased proteinuria of more than 3.5g in 24 hours; Reduced blood protein below 60g/liter, accompanied by decreased blood albumin below 30g/liter.; Blood cholesterol increased from 6.5mmol/liter or more; Appearance of birefringent fat granules and fat pillars in urine
Criteria 2 and 3 are mandatory in diagnosing nephrotic syndrome. The remaining standards may not be complete.
2. Clinical diagnosis
Simple nephrotic syndrome: When fully determining the diagnostic criteria for nephrotic syndrome, there are no symptoms of hypertension, hematuria or kidney failure.; Nephrotic syndrome is not simple: In addition to the diagnostic criteria for nephrotic syndrome, there is also the presence of hypertension, gross or microscopic hematuria, or accompanied by kidney failure.
3. Diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome according to cause
Causes of primary nephrotic syndrome include:
Minimal change glomerulopathy; Membranous glomerulonephritis: In some developing countries, membranous glomerulonephritis is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults; Focal sclerosing glomerulonephritis; Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis; Mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis; Extravascular proliferative glomerulonephritis
Secondary causes of nephrotic syndrome include drugs, toxins, autoimmune diseases, malignant diseases, genetic diseases, metabolic disorders, infections and parasites...
4. Diagnosis through histopathology
Minimal change glomerulopathy; Membranous glomerulonephritis; Focal sclerosing glomerulonephritis; Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis; Mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis; Extravascular proliferative glomerulonephritis.
5. Complications
People with nephrotic syndrome may have complications such as:
Infection: Acute or chronic infection occurs, most commonly cellulitis and peritonitis.; Embolism (thrombosis): Includes acute or chronic renal vein occlusion, limb vein and artery occlusion, iliac arteriovenous and splenic vein occlusion or, more rarely, pulmonary embolism.; Acute kidney failure.; Electrolyte disorders; Malnutrition; Complications due to medication use: Usually due to long-term use of corticosteroid drugs, or due to use of other immunosuppressants or diuretics.; Chronic renal failure.
If treatment is delayed, nephrotic syndrome can cause chronic kidney failure

Treatment of nephrotic syndrome
1. Treatment of secondary nephrotic syndrome:
Treatment depends on the cause of nephrotic syndrome
2. Specific treatment of primary nephrotic syndrome
Specific treatment is the use of corticosteroid therapy. During the first outbreak, in the attack phase, use prednisolone (corticoid group) for at least 4 weeks. If the patient responds well to treatment (24-hour urine test does not show proteinuria, or if it remains, it is only in trace form), the prednisolone dose will be gradually reduced.; However, patients need to continue taking prednisolone annually as prescribed by their doctor. If the patient does not respond to prednisolone, the doctor will instruct the patient to undergo a kidney biopsy, based on histopathology results to determine the next treatment direction.; In the treatment of relapses, for rare relapses (less than 1 time in 6 months), the doctor will apply the same treatment as the first phase. For frequent relapses (2 or more relapses in 6 months) or corticosteroid dependence, the doctor will use an attack dose similar to the first phase until the proteinuria stops. The patient must then use a prolonged maintenance dose, gradually reducing the dose until one year later.; Immunosuppressive drugs are used in the treatment of nephrotic syndrome or relapse, dependence, drug resistance or the appearance of serious side effects when using corticosteroids.
3. Treat symptoms
In the early stages, patients with nephrotic syndrome do not respond to treatment, and symptomatic treatment measures may then be necessary. These are the only treatments for nephrotic syndrome for cases with persistent symptoms that do not respond to any specific treatment. Symptomatic treatment options for this condition include:
Reduce edema: In the stage of severe edema, patients need to eat absolutely bland food. During the mild edema stage, you only need to eat relatively light meals. On average every day, a normal person eats about 4 - 6g of sodium, equivalent to 15g of salt (3 teaspoons). Eating relatively bland means consuming about 5g of salt per day, including in fish sauce and MSG. Because they also contain a certain amount of salt.; Use diuretics as prescribed by your doctor; Reduce protein in the diet:; In addition, plasma and albumin infusion is also needed (albumin infusion is performed when the blood albumin test is below 10g/l).; Lowering blood pressure: Measures to reduce average blood pressure or at least reduce systolic blood pressure help protect the kidneys. The group of antihypertensive drugs often prescribed by doctors are ACE inhibitors or angiotensin 2 receptor inhibitors. Sometimes without hypertension, these two groups of drugs can still be used due to their effect in reducing proteinuria.; When there is an infection, use antibiotics; Other drugs include inhibition of gastric acid secretion, calcium, vitamin D2, trace elements... to limit side effects of corticosteroids and consequences from proteinuria.

How to limit complications of nephrotic syndrome?
Changing your diet will greatly support the treatment of nephrotic syndrome, specifically:
Low-fat, low-salt diet; Discuss carefully with your doctor about the amount of protein you need to supplement and the amount of water you need to drink every day.; Avoid lying down too much and instead be active to help eliminate water and prevent blood clots.; Use medication as prescribed by your doctor, do not arbitrarily stop using medication, or arbitrarily buy medication for treatment.

Nutrition for people with kidney damage
Reduce sodium: Reducing sodium in your daily diet can improve high blood pressure and edema. Most of us consume large amounts of sodium from salt, which is found in most dishes. Therefore, the prerequisite for reducing sodium is reducing salt intake.; Choose foods rich in lean protein: Protein is essential for muscle growth and helps fight infection. Protein-rich foods that should be supplemented include eggs, poultry, fish, crab, shrimp, and beans; Need to reduce red meat. However, the amount of protein intake needs to change according to each period of illness. Patients need to discuss this issue carefully with their doctor. For example, in the stage of urinating a lot of protein, meaning the nephrotic syndrome is not yet stable, it is necessary to limit the amount of protein eaten; Limit the amount of water you drink when you have edema;; Limit potassium and phosphorus supplementation in cases of kidney failure due to nephrotic syndrome; Do not eat foods containing harmful fats such as saturated fat in milk and animal fat; fats found in processed foods, partially hydrogenated oils in fast food.; Reduce total cholesterol and LDL (bad cholesterol) through eating plenty of fresh fruits and fiber-rich vegetables.

How to care for patients with kidney failure?
1. Living and resting regime
Patients should rest in bed and keep their heads elevated, especially during periods of severe edema and oliguria.; Keep the sick person warm, especially in winter; Limit movement and movement while swelling is still severe.
2. Take care of hygiene
Every day you need to clean your teeth, mouth and ears, nose and throat. Clean the skin by bathing or washing with warm water depending on the severity of the condition. When taking care of patients with nephrotic syndrome, it is important to note that fingernails and toenails need to be cut short and clean, avoiding scratches that cause scratches on the skin, especially when the patient is in damp places that can easily cause superinfection.; Make sure bed linen, clothing and other items are always clean.; Detect ulcers early to treat patients by washing with physiological saline and hydrogen peroxide. Other complications need to be carefully monitored to have a treatment plan for the patient.
3. Monitor patients with nephrotic syndrome
Vital signs such as pulse, breathing rate, temperature,  blood pressure.; Monitor urine quantity and color; Monitor your weight every day.; Monitor edema; Monitor abdominal pain; Monitor for complications and side effects from corticosteroid medications.

However, the amount of protein intake needs to change according to each period of illness. Patients need to discuss this issue carefully with their doctor. For example, in the stage of urinating a lot of protein, meaning the nephrotic syndrome is not yet stable, it is necessary to limit the amount of protein eaten; Limit the amount of water you drink when you have edema;; Limit potassium and phosphorus supplementation in cases of kidney failure due to nephrotic syndrome; Do not eat foods containing harmful fats such as saturated fat in milk and animal fat; fats found in processed foods, partially hydrogenated oils in fast food.; Reduce total cholesterol and LDL (bad cholesterol) through eating plenty of fresh fruits and fiber-rich vegetables.

subsections.subsection_content:
1. Living and resting regime
Patients should rest in bed and keep their heads elevated, especially during periods of severe edema and oliguria.; Keep the sick person warm, especially in winter; Limit movement and movement while swelling is still severe.
2. Take care of hygiene
Every day you need to clean your teeth, mouth and ears, nose and throat. Clean the skin by bathing or washing with warm water depending on the severity of the condition. When taking care of patients with nephrotic syndrome, it is important to note that fingernails and toenails need to be cut short and clean, avoiding scratches that cause scratches on the skin, especially when the patient is in damp places that can easily cause superinfection.; Make sure bed linen, clothing and other items are always clean.; Detect ulcers early to treat patients by washing with physiological saline and hydrogen peroxide. Other complications need to be carefully monitored to have a treatment plan for the patient.
3. Monitor patients with nephrotic syndrome
Vital signs such as pulse, breathing rate, temperature,  blood pressure.; Monitor urine quantity and color; Monitor your weight every day.; Monitor edema; Monitor abdominal pain; Monitor for complications and side effects from corticosteroid medications.
